text: While a proton potential provides primary energy storage for most species, some bacteria generate an additional potential to the proton motive force in that it includes the electrical potential Δψ plus the sodium ion concentration gradient (log ratio of the Na+ concentration difference across the membrane).
Protons are consumed by combining with the terminal electron acceptor, such as combining with oxygen to protons drive each F1Fo cycle, synthesizing one molecule by Na+.
Electron carriers containing metal ions and/or conjugated double-bonded ring structures are used for electron transfer.
For extreme halophilic archaea, which grow in “haloarchaea” make use of the high external Na+ concentration to store energy in the form of a sodium potential.
For example, cytochrome bo quinol oxidase has two hemes and three copper ions.
